Widgets¶

The UIInput module provides a number of widget prefabs (in the Prefabs/UIElements folder). These prefabs are based on the standard Unity UI components, like Button and Slider, and add affordances to make the controls more intuitive to use with hands, especially in a VR setting. These affordances include depth-based animation on touch, drop shadows, and sound effects.

To use any widgets with hands, except the PhysicsButton, an instance of the LeapInputModule must be active in the scene. You can add this input module to a scene by adding the LeapEventSystem prefab to the hierarchy.

Button¶

The Button widget differs functionally from the standard Unity Button in that it separates the button game object into three parts instead of two. This allows both the button graphic and the text to float above the base of the image. The widget uses the CompressibleUI script to control the layer movement. A drop shadow and sound effetcs round out the prefab.

Slider¶

The Slider widget is structurally the same as a standard Unity Slider. The CompressibleUI component provides depth-based animation which, along with sound effects, provide feedback to the user as they manipulate the slider.

Toggle¶

The Toggle widget is set up as a push button rather than a checkbox like the standard Toggle control. The widget uses a helper script, ToggleToggler, to keep track of the button state. The ToggleToggler script is not intended to be used as-is. For most purposes, you should modify or replace this script. In other respects, the Toggle widget is the same as the Button widget.

Scroll View¶

The ScrollView widget is essentially identical to the standard scroll view, with sound effects the only addition. The widget prefab does contain an instance of the UIElementsPanel as example content.

UI Elements Panel¶

The UIElementsPanel is an example of a collection of hand-enabled widgets in a single panel. You can examine the structure of this widget to help understand how to put more complex UIs together.

Physics Button¶

The PhysicsButton widget works quite differently than the other UIInput widgets. Rather than project a putative cursor from the user’s hand, the physics button relies on physical contact. Like a real button, the physics button triggers when it is depressed far enough. The physics button contains a Unity Button component; you can hook the button up to other components in your scene like any other Unity button.

The primary component of the PhysicsButton prefab is the PhysicsUI script. This script observes the position of the button. If the button’s rigidbody is pushed back to its unsprung position, then the button’s relevant events are fired.
